title: Jump Off Joe (Washington)
text:
Jump off Joe is a <a href="butte">butte</a> in the <a href="Horse%20Heaven%20Hills">Horse Heaven Hills</a> south of <a href="Kennewick%2C%20Washington">Kennewick</a> in the U.S. state of <a href="Washington%20%28state%29">Washington</a>. Jump off Joe rises above the <a href="Tri-Cities%2C%20Washington">Tri-Cities</a> and is visible throughout much of the region, including in parts of <a href="Umatilla%20County%2C%20Oregon">Umatilla</a> and <a href="Morrow%20County%2C%20Oregon">Morrow</a> Counties in <a href="Oregon">Oregon</a> to the south. A gravel road approaches the summit from the south up a steep incline. On a clear day, visitors to the summit can see <a href="Mount%20Hood">Mount Hood</a>, <a href="Mount%20Adams%20%28Washington%29">Mount Adams</a> and <a href="Mount%20Rainier">Mount Rainier</a>.
Jump off Joe's high elevation compared to the surrounding area makes it an ideal location to place towers for radio and television communications. Among these is an <a href="amateur%20radio">amateur radio</a> repeater that provides coverage to much of the Columbia Basin. Two major local television stations, <a href="NBC">NBC</a> affiliate <a href="KNDU-TV">KNDU</a> and <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a> affiliate <a href="KVEW">KVEW</a> have their towers atop the butte. FM radio stations with transmitters on top of the butte include <a href="KUJ-FM">KUJ-FM</a> and <a href="KORD-FM">KORD-FM</a>.
Geology.
Jump off Joe and the greater Horse Heaven Hills are <a href="anticline">anticline</a>s within the <a href="Yakima%20Fold%20Belt">Yakima Fold Belt</a>. The belt is a series of fault lines extending throughout south-central Washington which are part of the larger <a href="Olympic%E2%80%93Wallowa%20Lineament">Olympic–Wallowa Lineament</a>. The lineament runs from <a href="Port%20Angeles%2C%20Washington">Port Angeles</a> to the <a href="Wallowa%20Mountains">Wallowa Mountains</a> in northeastern Oregon.
Rocks in the area are predominantly basalt, part of the <a href="Columbia%20River%20Basalt%20Group">Columbia River Basalt Group</a>. Lava flows believed to have originated from the <a href="Yellowstone%20hotspot">Yellowstone hotspot</a> approximately 10 to 15 million years ago when the hotspot was located in western <a href="Idaho">Idaho</a>. These lava flows covered large portions of Washington and Oregon all the way to the Pacific Ocean in basalt up to thick.
During the <a href="Last%20Glacial%20Maximum">Last Glacial Maximum</a>, ice sheets extended into what is today the <a href="Idaho%20Panhandle">Idaho Panhandle</a>, blocking the flow of the <a href="Clark%20Fork%20River">Clark Fork River</a> creating <a href="Glacial%20Lake%20Missoula">Glacial Lake Missoula</a>. Over a period of 2,000 years the weight of the water behind this ice dam caused it to break sending a surge of water toward the Pacific Ocean. This water would backup at the Horse Heaven Hills, flowing through and deepening <a href="Wallula%20Gap">Wallula Gap</a> located a few miles southeast.
Climate and ecology.
Jump off Joe lies in a <a href="semi-arid">semi-arid</a> environment within the <a href="rain%20shadow">rain shadow</a> of the <a href="Cascade%20Mountains">Cascade Mountains</a>. Being nearly above the <a href="Columbia%20River">Columbia River</a>, Jump off Joe receives more snow than the Tri-Cities and can remain snow covered for much of the winter season. High winds in the area provide an excellent setting for <a href="wind%20turbines">wind turbines</a> to generate power. Like most of the Mid Columbia, the butte is treeless. Plant life includes native grasses and <a href="sagebrush">sagebrush</a>.
Annual rainfall at the nearest airport, the <a href="Tri-Cities%20Airport%20%28Washington%29">Tri-Cities Airport</a> in <a href="Pasco%2C%20Washington">Pasco</a> is . Afternoon temperatures in the summer can exceed . Jump off Joe frequently lies above <a href="Inversion%20%28meteorology%29">inversions</a> that form in the Columbia Basin during <a href="high%20pressure">high pressure</a> systems in the winter months.
